questions.text: Which of the following statements about the protoporphyrin ring and its associated metals is incorrect?

choices.text: Heme is a derivative of porphyrin, a cyclic compound formed by the fusion of 4 pyrrole rings with a metallic group in the center
Heme-containing proteins such as myoglobin have Fe3+ as the metallic group.
Heme-containing enzymes are catalase, peroxidase, and nitric oxide synthase.
The metallic group in Chlorophyll is magnesium, while in cytochrome a/a3 is copper.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Heme-containing proteins such as Myoglobin have Fe3+ as the metallic group.

 

Explanation:

Heme is composed of a protoporphyrin ring with a metallic group (Fe2+) in the center. (Option A)

 

Porphyrin derived proteins

Metallic group in the center

Heme

  • Heme-containing proteins - Hemoglobin, Myoglobin, some cytochromes
  • Heme-containing enzymes- catalase, peroxidase, nitric oxide synthase (Option C)

Iron (Fe2+)

Hematin (Oxidized form of Heme)

Iron (Fe3+)

Cytochrome a/a3 (Option D)

Copper

Chlorophyll

Magnesium

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy is brought to the clinic by his parents due to severe photosensitivity and recurrent skin lesions that worsen upon sun exposure. The parents are paint factory workers living in an industrial complex. The child’s urine is noted to be dark red in color. Laboratory tests confirm elevated levels of porphyrins in the blood. Which of the following statements about the diagnosis is incorrect?

choices.text: The condition can occur due to exposure to lead, leading to decreased activity of ALA synthase.
The red fluorescence of the teeth under UV light is referred to as erythrodontia, due to emission of 600 nm wavelength by porphyrin.
Porphyrin has a specific absorption band called Soret band corresponding to 400 nm.
Photosensitivity due to the accumulation of porphyrins in the skin which release superoxide radicals causing photooxidative damage.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) The condition can occur due to exposure to lead, leading to decreased activity of ALA synthase.

 

Explanation:

The condition described is more likely a type of porphyria, which involves elevated porphyrins and can occur due to lead exposure. However, the enzyme ALA synthase is not affected by lead.

Lead primarily inhibits 3 enzymes of heme synthesis:

  • Ferrochelatase
  • ALA dehydratase
  • Copro-porphyrinogen oxidase

 

Option B:

  • The 4 pyrrole rings in Porphyrins are connected by methenyl bridges (double bonds) capable of absorbing light at 400 nm and emitting light at 600 nm.
  • This 600 nm wavelength appears as the red fluorescence of the teeth under UV light, which is referred to as Erythrodontia. This property of porphyrins is being used in cancer phototherapy

 

  • Since tumors often take up more porphyrins than do normal tissues, hematoporphyrin or related compounds are administered to a patient with an appropriate tumor. The tumor is then exposed to an argon laser to excite the porphyrins, producing cytotoxic effects.


 

The light absorbed by porphyrins has a specific absorption band called the Soret band (Option C), which corresponds to around 400 nm as seen on spectrometry.

 

 

Photosensitivity in porphyria is due to the accumulation of porphyrins in the skin (Option D). Porphyrins absorb light of shorter wavelengths (higher energy) and emit longer wavelengths (lower energy), which in turn releases superoxide radicals causing photooxidative damage.

questions.text:
Which of the following structures correctly represents the type of porphyrin?



 

 

 

 

 

A= acetyl, P=propionyl, M=methyl, V=vinyl

choices.text: A- Uroporphyrinogen I, B- Uroporphyrinogen III, E- Protoporphyrinogen I
D- Coproporphyrinogen III, C- Coproporphyrinogen I, E- Protoporphyrinogen I
A- Uroporphyrinogen III, B- Uroporphyrinogen I, E- Protoporphyrinogen III
D- Coproporphyrinogen I, C- Coproporphyrinogen III, E- Protoporphyrinogen III

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D. D- Coproporphyrinogen I, C- Coproporphyrinogen III, E- Protoporphyrinogen III

 

Explanation:

 

Porphyrins can exist in multiple forms depending on the group in the possible 8 positions of 4 pyrrole rings.

 

Uroporphyrinogen

 
  • Alternating acetyl (A) and propionyl (P) groups at all 8 positions.
  • Uroporphyrinogen I is when there is symmetry in all the rings.
  • Uroporphyrinogen III is when there is an asymmetry in the last ring.

Coproporphyrinogen

 
  • Instead of acetyl, methyl (M) groups are present.
  • The conversion from the acetyl to the methyl group is done by decarboxylation.
  • Uroporphyrinogen decarboxylase converts uroporphyrinogen to coproporphyrinogen.

Protoporphyrinogen
  • In this case, a methyl (M)-vinyl (V) group is present only in rings 1 and 2.
  • Coproporphyrinogen oxidase converts coproporphyrinogen to protoporphyrinogen.
  • Protoporphyrinogen can be converted into protoporphyrin by oxidation (removal of hydrogen) by protoporphyrinogen oxidase.

questions.text: According to the given image of heme synthesis, which of the following statements is incorrect?

choices.text: Steps c and d occur in Mitochondria, while steps a and b occur in the cytosol.
The enzyme involved in step a) is Uroporphyrinogen decarboxylase
4 molecules of CO2 are liberated at step a)
Ferrochelatase is the enzyme involved in step d)

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Steps c and d occur in Mitochondria, while steps a and b occur in the cytosol.

 

Explanation:

Step b represents the synthesis of Protoporphyrinogen III from Coproporphyrinogen III, which occurs in mitochondria.

 

 

 

 

 

 

Heme Synthesis:

 

Step

Reaction

Enzyme

Location

Key Points

1

Succinyl CoA + Glycine → Delta-aminolevulinic acid (ALA)

ALA Synthase

Mitochondria

Rate-limiting step; requires pyridoxal phosphate as a cofactor

2

2 ALA → Porphobilinogen (PBG)

ALA Dehydratase

Cytoplasm

It involves removal of 2 molecules of water; the enzyme contains zinc and is inhibited by lead

3

4 PBG → Hydroxymethylbilane (HMB)

Uroporphyrinogen I Synthase

Cytoplasm

-

4a

HMB → Uroporphyrinogen I

Spontaneous cyclization

Cytoplasm

-

4b

HMB → Uroporphyrinogen III

Uroporphyrinogen III Synthase

Cytoplasm

-

5

Uroporphyrinogen III → Coproporphyrinogen III

Uroporphyrinogen Decarboxylase

(Option B)

Cytoplasm

Decarboxylation, removal of 4 molecules of CO2 (Option C)

6

Coproporphyrinogen III → Protoporphyrinogen III

Coproporphyrinogen Oxidase

Mitochondria

  

7

Protoporphyrinogen III → Protoporphyrin III

Protoporphyrinogen Oxidase

Mitochondria

  

8

Protoporphyrin III → Heme

Ferrochelatase

(Option D)

Mitochondria

Insertion of Fe2+

questions.text: Which of the following statements about heme synthesis is incorrect?

choices.text: ALA synthase requires pyridoxal phosphate as a cofactor.
ALA dehydratase contains zinc as a cofactor and is inhibited by lead.
Pyridoxal phosphate deficiency can lead to anemia due to impaired ALA synthase activity.
ALA dehydratase is the rate-limiting step of the heme synthesis pathway.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D. ALA dehydratase is the rate-limiting step of the heme synthesis pathway.

 

Explanation:

ALA dehydratase is not the rate-limiting step of heme synthesis; ALA synthase is the rate-limiting enzyme in this pathway.

 

  • Option A: ALA synthase requires pyridoxal phosphate as a cofactor for the synthesis of delta-aminolevulinic acid (ALA).

 

 

  • Option B: ALA dehydratase contains zinc as a cofactor and its activity is inhibited by lead.
  • Option C: Pyridoxal phosphate deficiency can lead to anemia because it impairs ALA synthase activity, reducing heme synthesis.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents with microcytic anemia and elevated delta-aminolevulinic acid (ALA). Which statement correctly describes the regulation of ALA synthase I (ALAS I) and ALA synthase II (ALAS II)?

choices.text: ALAS I is primarily expressed in erythroid tissues and regulated by iron.
ALAS II is ubiquitously expressed and inhibited by heme.
ALAS I is inhibited by heme and primarily expressed in the liver.
ALAS II is regulated by heme and is key in hepatic heme synthesis.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) ALAS I is inhibited by heme and primarily expressed in the liver.

Explanation:


Regulation of ALA Synthase I and II:

 

Feature

ALAS I (Non-Erythroid)

ALAS II (Erythroid)

Expression Location

Primarily in the liver

Erythroid tissues

Regulation by Heme

Inhibited by heme

Not regulated by heme

Regulation by Iron

Not regulated by iron

Regulated by iron availability

Role in Heme Synthesis

The rate-limiting enzyme in hepatic heme synthesis

Key enzyme in erythroid heme synthesis

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presents with fatigue, weakness, and pallor. Blood tests reveal microcytic anemia with elevated serum iron and ferritin levels. Bone marrow biopsy shows ringed sideroblasts. Genetic testing confirms a mutation in the ALAS2 gene. What is the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Iron deficiency anemia
Thalassemia
X-linked sideroblastic anemia
Autosomal recessive sideroblastic anemia

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) X-linked sideroblastic anemia

 

Explanation:

 

  • X-linked sideroblastic anemia (XLSA) is caused by mutations in the ALAS2 gene, which is responsible for the enzyme 5-aminolevulinate synthase 2, essential for the first step in heme synthesis.
  • This condition typically presents with microcytic, hypochromic anemia, elevated serum iron and ferritin levels, and ringed sideroblasts in the bone marrow.
  • The confirmed mutation in the ALAS2 gene in the patient points to XLSA, distinguishing it from other forms of anemia.
  • Overactivation of ALAS2 gene causes x linked protoporphyria

 

Differences Between X-Linked and Autosomal Recessive Sideroblastic Anemia:

Characteristic

X-Linked Sideroblastic Anemia (XLSA)

Autosomal Recessive Sideroblastic Anemia (ARSA)

(Option D)

Genetic Cause

Mutation in the ALAS2 gene

Mutations in various genes involved in glycine transport into mitochondria, including SLC25A38 and GLRX5

Gender Predominance

Primarily affects males

It affects both males and females equally

Clinical Presentation

Microcytic, hypochromic anemia; ringed sideroblasts; increased serum iron and ferritin

Microcytic anemia; ringed sideroblasts; variable symptoms

Pathway Affected

Heme synthesis (5-aminolevulinate synthase 2)

Mitochondrial function, iron-sulfur cluster biogenesis

Common Symptoms

Fatigue, pallor, weakness

Fatigue, pallor, weakness; potential systemic symptoms

Diagnosis

Genetic testing for ALAS2 mutations

Genetic testing for specific gene mutations

Management Options

Pyridoxine, iron chelation, blood transfusions

Iron chelation, blood transfusions, supportive therapies

 

  • Iron Deficiency Anemia (Option A) is characterized by low serum iron and ferritin levels, which do not match the elevated levels seen in the case.
  • Thalassemia (Option B) involves defective globin chain production and normal iron levels, unlike the elevated iron levels and ringed sideroblasts present here.

questions.text:
Match the following disorders with the enzyme defects in context to relation synthesis.

 


	
		
			
			Enzyme defect
			
			
			Disorder
			
		
		
			
			A. Uroporphyrinogen III synthase
			
			
			i) Porphyria cutanea tarda
			
		
		
			
			B. Uroporphyrinogen decarboxylase defect
			
			
			ii) Congenital erythropoietic porphyria
			
		
		
			
			C.  ALA synthase II
			
			
			iii) Acute intermittent porphyria
			
		
		
			
			D.  Porphobilinogen deaminase
			
			
			iv) X-linked sideroblastic anemia

choices.text: A-ii, B-i, C-iv, D-iii
A-iii, B-iv, C-ii, D-i
A-iv, B-iii, C-i, D-ii
A-i, B-ii, C-iv, D-iii

questions.solution:
Every defect in the enzyme involved in heme synthesis is associated with a disorder, as shown below:

 

Enzyme defect

Disorder

ALA synthase II

X-linked sideroblastic anemia

ALA dehydratase

ALA dehydratase deficienct porphyria

Porphobilinogen deaminase (Hydroxymethylbilane synthase)

Acute intermittent porphyria

Uroporphyrinogen III synthase

Congenital erythropoietic porphyria

Uroporphyrinogen decarboxylase

Porphyria cutanea tarda

Coproporphyrinogen oxidase

Hereditary coproporphyria

Protoporphyrinogen oxidase

Porphyria variegata

Ferro chelatase

Erythropoietic protoporphyria

questions.text:
Match the following disorder with its clinical classification:


	
		
			
			Disorder
			
			
			Clinical Manifestations
			
		
		
			
			A.Acute intermittent porphyria
			
			
			i) Neuropsychiatric manifestations
			
		
		
			
			B.Porphyria Cutanea Tarda
			
			
			ii) Photosensitivity
			
		
		
			
			C.Hereditary coproporphyria
			
			
			iii) Both Neuropsychiatric manifestation and photosensitivity
			
		
		
			
			D.Congenital erythropoietic porphyria

choices.text: A-i, B-ii, C-iii, D-ii
A-i, B-ii, C-ii, D-iii
A-ii, B-i, C-iii, D-iii
A-ii, B-i, C-ii, D-iii

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) A-i, B-ii, C-iii, D-ii

 

Explanation:

 

Porphyria can be classified into 3 categories based on their important clinical manifestations:

 

  • Cutaneous photosensitivity is due to accumulation of porphyrins in the skin, which enhances the production of free radicals upon exposure to light.
  • Neurological complications often arise from severe episodes of acute attacks. These attacks can also trigger neuropsychiatric symptoms like confusion, hallucinations, anxiety, and psychosis. However, these symptoms are typically self-limiting.
  • CEP and PCT present with blistering photosensitivity whereas EP and X linked protoprphyria present with non blistering protoporphyria\

Werewolf appearance of blistering cutaneous manifestations

questions.text: Lead poisoning can cause acquired porphyria by inhibiting several enzymes in the heme synthesis pathway. Which of the following enzymes is not affected by lead poisoning?

choices.text: ALA dehydratase
Coproporphyrinogen oxidase
Ferrochelatase
ALA synthase

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D. ALA synthase

Explanation:
Lead poisoning can lead to acquired porphyria by inhibiting 3 enzymes of the heme synthesis pathway:

Enzyme inhibited

Features

ALA dehydratase (Option A)

ALA elevation

Coproporphyrinogen oxidase (Option B)

Coproporphyrin elevation

Ferrochelatase (Option C)

Elevated Zinc protoporphyrin levels (Most sensitive marker)
